main.opener: You get the sense something's been building lately?
variants: People are tense. Things are different since Halden died.
Work has gotten strange. I don't exactly belong there anymore.
Nobody really talks to me at the Directorate these days.
It feels like things are... closing in.
Yeah. Since Halden—nothing works like it used to.
At the Directorate, I did something they didn't like. Now I'm almost cut out.
My access is nearly gone. Desk flagged, people keep their distance.
Some of my colleagues... I don't know if they even see me now.
It's hard to know who’s watching, or why.
Definitely. After Halden—everything destabilized. Blackouts, all the job mix-ups, then the mural. What a mess.
I was in the Directorate when the BCI failures started. Trust just fell apart.

Now my BCI score is basically zero. I'm under watch every minute.
It’s isolating. You feel like a ghost.
It’s been chaos since Halden died. First the BCI threw everyone into the wrong roles, then that mural—did you see it?
I work in the Directorate—used to—flagging patterns, mostly. Sounds dull, but it meant access.
Honestly, seeing the harm this system did broke something in me. So I leaked 'The Ledger,' all those people hurt for nothing.
Once the data hit public channels, protests erupted. I lost everything: clearance, connections, even my apartment's priority.
My score dropped off a cliff. Friends won't meet my eyes. Even walking in here feels risky now.
I know some people think it was worth it, but I’m not sure anymore. Everything’s turned upside down.
Feels like I detonated my own life just for people to finally pay attention.
Yeah. Everything’s been building to this—Halden’s death exposed how fake the system’s control really was.
At the Directorate, I flagged outlier behaviors for years, believing the BCI made life safer. I was wrong. The more I saw, the more I realized it punished small difference, erased people for numbers.
I lean Innovator—I thought transparency and better systems could fix things. But nobody listened. Not until the mural, not until the failures started affecting the Council itself.
I used my clearance to leak 'The Ledger.' The archive confirmed our worst fears—false positives, silent erasures, families ruined for compliance scores.
The fallout was instant. The Council’s fractured, protests everywhere, and people who vanished came back as leaders.
My colleagues act like I’m contagious. My score’s at the bottom. I can’t get basic permits, my place feels watched.
It’s lonely. I thought starting this would help. Instead, it just made my whole life... exposed.
Hard to tell if I did the right thing, or if I just made myself a target. It’s... scary.
main.emotion: exposed, uncertain, and a little scared

emotional.opener: Oksana, you did what you thought was right. No one deserves to feel alone for trying to make things better. Whatever happens, that matters.
variants: Maybe. It's hard to say.
Thanks. I hear you.
I get what you're saying. It's just... complicated.
Appreciate you saying that. Not everyone does.
Still hard to know if it really makes a difference.
Sometimes I forget that other people notice.
Feels like there's always a line you cross, even if you don't mean to.
It helps to hear someone say it out loud.
Makes things a little easier to hold, I guess.
I can't remember the last time someone reminded me of that.
I've started to wonder if I'm losing perspective. Or maybe this is just what happens here.
Sometimes all it takes is one person noticing.
You saying it matters more than I expected.
It's almost enough to make me believe I didn't lose myself completely.
You know, I never planned to stand out. I never wanted to be noticed for the wrong reasons.
But it's strange how quickly a city can turn, how you can become invisible the moment you step out of line.
What you just said... it cuts through the noise. Makes me feel seen, even for a second.
I've always believed the system could work, if there was room for people in it.
Being reminded that I'm not alone, even briefly, makes a difference.
So thank you. Maybe that's enough for tonight.
